Using knitractive with Julia

Jeroen Janssens

2020-03-17

Source: vignettes/examples/julia.Rmd
julia.Rmd

View the corresponding julia.Rmd file.

In this example, we’re using the julia docker image to run Julia.

               _
   _       _ _(_)_     |  Documentation: https://docs.julialang.org
  (_)     | (_) (_)    |
   _ _   _| |_  __ _   |  Type "?" for help, "]?" for Pkg help.
  | | | | | | |/ _` |  |
  | | |_| | | | (_| |  |  Version 1.3.1 (2019-12-30)
 _/ |\__'_|_|_|\__'_|  |  Official https://julialang.org/ release
|__/                   |

Two-dimensional arrays use space-separated values and semicolon-separated rows:

julia> M = [1 2; 3 4]
2×2 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  2
 3  4

You can use certain unicode characters as variable names. This is especially handy for mathematical notation:

julia> M * π
2×2 Array{Float64,2}:
 3.14159   6.28319
 9.42478  12.5664

While loops loop while a condition is true:

julia> for animal in ["dog", "cat", "mouse"]
           println("$animal is a mammal")
       end
dog is a mammal
cat is a mammal
mouse is a mammal
